Reviews.Title: Good adventure cam, especially for the price.
Reviews.Author: R. Zamudio
Reviews.Content: I almost did not buy this camera, having read the reviews from my phone while standing in the store aisle. I figured I would give it a try and return it if I ran into the same problems. I was looking for a camera with adventure-oriented toughness at a reasonable price, and this is one of the few on the market. It seems as if most consumers are ignoring the cardinal rule regarding use of technology: You have to be "smarter" than the device you are attempting to use.The most frequent complaint I have read is on the claim of the camera being waterproof. In response to this, I purposely pushed this camera to it's rated limit of 16 ft depths several times during scuba training and snorkeling trips without issue. I have owned $1400 diving cameras with waterproof housings, and this one takes shots and video at shallow depths just as good as the more expensive models, and without the bulkiness of a waterproof housing. I also realize how important the seals are on an underwater camera, so I regularly clean the seals at the battery compartment and apply a bit of chap stick with my pinky to keep a good pliable seal. But since this is not a full-blown underwater camera, it requires some careful handling. If you remember from middle-school science class, pressure is a measurement of force, and this camera is rated at depths where the force of water acting on the camera is roughly 7 pounds per sq. inch. This means that if the camera is exposed to a force of water greater than 7 PSI, chances are the seals will be overwhelmed and fail. This can happen while trying to take this camera surfing and having a wave crash on top of you. This can happen if you were to drop it off of a fairly high bridge into water. It can happen if it is in your pocket when you are in water and your movements are trapping and forcing water against the camera. It can happen if you are going down a fast slide at a waterpark with the camera and hit the splashdown pool with speed. This is a sensitive electronic device, and should be treated as such within what the manufacturer recommends. With this being said, the camera has worked great for me in aqueous situations. The neoprene case that was included with mine acts as a flotation device for the camera. The camera by itself will not float, but I have seen a floating wrist strap for sale that should do the trick.I have not dropped it with the exception of it sliding off of the countertop and hitting the tile, and it still works. I guess this is not bad, considering other cameras and even higher-end mobile electronics like iPhones have sustained irreparable damage from falls of less severity.I would say the dustproof claim falls under the same claim of waterproof since it relies on the same seals. Havent had to test it, but it is nice to be able to just rinse the entire camera under a faucet when it starts getting grimey. Just don't plan on dragging this behind a dune buggy and having a functioning camera.The freezeproof claim is based upon battery type, which in this case is a Lithium-ion type. Lithium-based batteries are lighter than most other battery types and have greater resistance to cold. Cold temps slow the chemical reaction in batteries and causes a drop in output until they are warmed. For this reason, I use lithium-based batteries in my headlamps for hiking in cold weather. Another bonus to Lithium-ion batteries is that they last very long and do not develop a charge-memory that can cause a drop in overall charge capacity.Picture quality is very good for a point-and-shoot. I do not use the full 14MP quality in my photos because I frequently send photos through emails, and the size of 14MP photos would clog people's inboxes and take too long to upload and download. (Grandma, get Cable. Dial-up sucks!) Even at mid-quality settings, the photos are still more than good enough to take to Costco and have made into enlarged prints. Mind you, the "intelligent" settings on most cameras cannot make up for common sense of the user. If it is dark out, and the intelligent setting is trying to use "face" mode or anything other than "night" mode, it would probably be best to override the settings manually. Don't blame the camera completely for lousy shots in lousy conditions if you do not notice it is in a mode not suited for those conditions.In conclusion, this is a great camera that can take a bit more abuse than others on the market and has great picture quality, all for under two hundred dollars. It is nice to have a point and shoot camera that; won't be totalled by accidently falling in while crossing a river or stream, isn't at the mercy of the couple grains of sand jamming the protruding lens assembly, and won't have a near-dead battery on the slopes of a snowy mountain. As for extreme action sports in similar elements, you will most likely want a camera that has a separate housing to provide water and shock protection.

Reviews.Title: Works fine so far. Nice pictures and vide
Reviews.Author: khp
Reviews.Content: After ruining 2 digital cameras on outdoor trips. One was sat on and one drowned under my raingear I decided to get a rugged waterproof camera for around use.  I looked at all the reviews for these type of cameras. I was looking at the Pentax wp90 and the Panasonic TS2.  I really wanted the Pentax WP90 but there was a lot of complaining about the image quality from the reviews.  Then I looked at the Panasonic TS2 and the reviews all said great things about the images but I could not find one anywhere online for a good price.  I finally was sick of reading reviews and hunting for cameras online and went to the nearest Costco and picked up a Fuji film XP20.  I figured the price was right and I had 90 days to return it if I didn't like it.  I just wanted a rugged point and shoot camera that can survive hiking, canoeing, and skiing.  I don't plan on swimming with it.  First day with it and I'll happy with this camera.  Pictures and videos are great.  Easy to use. Quick to get pictures.  Kind of tricky to hold but still a fine camera so far. Time will tell how rugged it is but the images are good enough for me.

Reviews.Title: Audio is out-of-sync
Reviews.Author: H. Wang "jwangamazon"
Reviews.Content: I got the Fuji XP20 mainly for taking videos in conditions that my Canon HD camcorder can not. On my first usage in a river rafting event, I already see the problems with this camera:1) I am experienced with Camera and camcorders, I know how to hold them properly. But the lens head is placed in a very awkward place, your fingers will easily cover part of the lens head. So, don't be surprised to see your fingers in the final photos and video clips. It's almost for sure that you will not get photos or videos of yourself. Because other people may not be able to hold this camera properly to take yours.2) Hard to fine tune the zoom speed. Not convenient, but I can live with that.3) The camera won't focus while zooming (it will focus after zooming stops). This is a typical issue with non-DSLR camera in video mode. I saw the same thing in Panasonic camera also. Not a big issue to me.4) This is the biggest flaw, the audio is not in sync with the video. I have to turn off the audio from the video clips, and add background music when producing the final movie for the rafting trip. Even my simple Flip video camera handle this better than this Fuji camera.5) The video quality is no way to compare with regular HD camcorder. The image is kind of grainy, even at 1pm strong sunshine with good light. Again, I can accept this since I am in a condition (around water) where normal camcorder can not be used.6) Indoor photo quality is no way to compare with my 5-year-old 5MP Panasonic camera.But this is OK to me since I am in a condition (around water) where my normal camera can not be used.If this is the only camera you want to have, I won't recommend this. However, if your intend is "ONLY" to take photos, videos in conditions where your normal gears can not, then I think this Fuju XP20 is acceptable....if you don't mind the out-of-sync audio problem.

Reviews.Title: Not for surfing (nor maybe ANY action water sport)
Reviews.Author: Nicholas P. Kiefer "keefah"
Reviews.Content: Everything about this camera makes you want to buy it -- price (Costco discount), the durability/waterproof aspect, style... then you get it home and everything seems cool -- take a few shots around the house, video your dog. Very good image quality. So next step -- take it out to do what you bought it for: water/action/rugged whatever. I took mine surfing today, first time. I read all the precautions about how to keep water out, particularly the part where the battery is housed. First thing I noticed is the strap is not meant for a water sport at all! Why didn't they include some kind of cool floating and/or rubber strap that would allow it to stay on you while you paddle or whatever? Ok, so I'm navigating the dopey regular strap, take a few shots, but then I start to realize that the button positioning and sensitivity make trying to hold it and navigate waves just stupid. It is very easy to accidentally press buttons you don't intend to, and there is no "normal" way to hold it for shooting pictures, let alone action pictures. I took a bunch of unintended videos too. The clincher was when the cover housing the battery popped open! Oops, water in the camera, game over! If this battery cover that absolutely cannot be allowed to get wet can POP OPEN during water action activity...?? Screw that! So I'm taking it back to Costco today. Fortunately, I found this out during my first 30 days. I'm going to exchange it and try again, giving the benefit of the doubt that this was a bad apple, but I'm still kind of turned off by the design and button sensitivity. I guess it was more made for Moms and kids at the beach as opposed to actual water sports. Oh well. I was actually able to salvage the sd card and look at the photos. Very nice image quality, I will give it that, though many of them have water dropplets in the shot (not sure how to prevent that). Video quality very nice, with sound too. I'd say fine as long as you aren't really going to be "rugged" with it at all.

Reviews.Title: xp20 self destructs!
Reviews.Author: Zaxxon
Reviews.Content: Like another reviewer my battery cover popped open underwater! Not cool for an "underwater" camera.  The two tiny 'latch' sliders on the xp20 (one is the actual 'open' slider the other is apparently the 'lock' - the manual states both have to be set snugly against the 'closed' edge - but they are suffiently exposed to cause some slight friction to allow the hatch to literally 'spring' open) are a change from the arrangement on the xp10, not a good redesign in my estimation, after a over a hundred hours of underwater videos on the xp10 vs. less than an hour with the xp20 before the hatch opened and the camera self destructed.  I bought this as a 'refurbished' unit online thru ebay, we'll see if anyone along the line is going to be 'accountable'.  The picture quality underwater in 720p is very good, I like Fuji camera products, but this design needs to be rethought.  If you buy one of these units, buy it from a local outlet so you can return it in person should the latch failure occur.  The design of the battery/sd card 'hatch' cover makes this unit a very questionable buy if your intent is underwater shooting - good luck!

Reviews.Title: Bang for the Buck
Reviews.Author: Robert M
Reviews.Content: I have had this for a couple of weeks now.  This is a great little camera for the price.  Takes really good photos, small enough to fit into your pocket or life vest, or jacket.  Battery was charged when I first got it and it still shows completely charged even after taking some video, and about 100 photos.  I dropped it from 5 ft onto the concrete and watched it bounce, thinking there went $100 down the drain, and it was alive and kicking, not a scratch on it.  Plunked it into water and took a photo with it.  The only down side, so far, is the SD card is hard to retrieve with the battery in, but easy to put back in with the battery in.  Controls are easy to get to.  A little to easy, I have hit the video button more than once by accident.  I got this for kayaking and outdoors stuff and it fits right into the kayak LJ and is hardly noticeable in my shorts pockets.  2 thumbs up.  I had looked at more expensive ones, on review sites, and I am so far very glad I bought this.  It was the 8th pick out of the 10 waterproof cameras that were reviewed, 1 thru 7 were all way more expensive.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm xp 20
Reviews.Author: Jamie
Reviews.Content: I bought my camera about a year ago and it worked fine. I was so excited about the camera and I bought the accessory kit to go with it. I took it underwater all the time which the picture quality is amazing. and even took it on vacation on a Disney Cruise to the Bahamas and Disney World and Universal Studios in Feb. I love the picture quality of this camera an the video quality.  On the Fourth of July though, I accidently dropped it two feet from the ground on carpet with the extra protection the rubber piece in the accessory kit it's supposed to give, and the dang thing broke. So much for shockproof. I tried getting it fixed but getting it fixed would have cost about the same amount as the camera is worth, or I could buy a different camera, same functions, different brand, lower cost. I bought a new camera and crossing fingers this one lasts more than a year.

Reviews.Title: Poor design
Reviews.Author: Jann
Reviews.Content: Purchased camera because it appeared "durable".  There was nothing about this camera that I liked. Returned it to Costco.  Video quality outside was poor at best.  Attempted to video my daughter riding her horse during a Dressage test (very slow paced activity).  It picked up reflections from trees at the other end of the court.  The indoor flash light was continously on when needing to spontaneous low light pictures.  I am not an avid camera/video user, I found this camera NOT user friendly.  Still searching for a point and shot.

Reviews.Title: It is ok
Reviews.Author: Mar
Reviews.Content: The display screen is blury and a red tone to it the moment I started to use it. I thought It was the settings but its not. It is only blurry when you are taking the pictures, but once the picture is taken it is a clear photo. I have not printed any pictures yet. I love the underwater use. This is my second underwater cameras and I have to say that Olympus was better. I now know that I should stick to a company that I have used before and prefer. As for now I will stay with this camera and whenever it dies is when I'll get a new one. I advise people not to get it.

Reviews.Title: XP20 died, worst camera and  waste of money
Reviews.Author: John Ziemienski
Reviews.Content: Don't waste your money on Fujifilm cameras. I bought this camera for my niece, and it died on her college research semester in Australia. She only took a couple of pictures just below the water line (around a foot) and the camera died. This camera is not waterproof as advertised, as it is advertised to work down to 16 feet. I will never buy a Fujifilm product again. I recommend folks to stay with Canon or Nikon for quality products.

Reviews.Title: Disappointing!
Reviews.Author: Glenn Ikemoto
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera approximately two years ago to replace a DSLR camera that I accidentally "drowned" in the Kenai River.  I wanted a camera that would shoot decent still photos and videos, but could withstand a little dunking in the wilderness.  Ironically, I never got to take this camera to Alaska as intended.When I first got this camera, I wanted to see how well it took photos underwater.  So, on only two occasions, holding the camera just below the surface of waist-deep water, I took a couple of photos of the bottom of a swimming pool.  The photos were satisfactory, but not outstanding.  Those were the only times that the camera was ever underwater.  It never even got rained on.  I simply used it to take "everyday" snapshots.  Again, the only time this camera has touched water was two years ago.A few weeks ago, I attempted to change the battery, but the latch on the battery/SD card cover would not work.  It seemed that the spring was broken, and the latch could not be opened.  I sent the camera to the FujiFilm repair center in New Jersey for what seemed to be a simple repair.Within a week, I received a written estimate for repair for the camera.  The estimated cost of repair was precisely $6.00 less than what I paid for the camera brand-new!  The estimate stated that not only was the latch broken, but the "camera has WATER DAMAGE (capitalization added) and is beyond repair!"  Where did the water damage come from?The user's manual was very careful to point out that the cover for the battery compartment needed to be pressed tightly with the tip of your finger until a second "click" was heard to ensure proper closure.  Accordingly, I made sure that I heard that "click" each time I closed the cover.  And, as far as I could tell, until the latch wouldn't open, the camera was working just fine.To have Fuji tell me that there was catastrophic water damage when the camera has not touched water in two years is extremely disappointing!  Basically, it tells me that this camera does not perform as it was intended.  It also tells me that, whatever method they're using, Fuji's waterproofing is inadequate or substandard.  To repeat, WHERE did the water damage come from?To be fair, I found the camera to be small and handy and fine to take point-and-shoot snapshots.But, I will not buy another FujiFilm "waterproof" camera, and I cannot, in good conscience, recommend that anyone else do so.  I'll take a different "waterproof camera" with me to Alaska.

Reviews.Title: BUY A NEW ONE EVERY YEAR!
Reviews.Author: NOHUHU
Reviews.Content: That's what's bound to happen if you purchase the Fuji XP series.  Mine lasted just over a year of occasional and careful use around boats, (always rinsed).  The door froze shut on my last trip and I had to force the door open to get my memory and battery out.Yes- the pictures are often fuzzy, and off color.  Yes- the flash is slow.  Yes- the Video quality is c**p.  Yes- the seal is bound to leak or fail.It was compact, fun and easy to use while it lasted, but only has a 1 year warranty.  Wasting >$150/year is ridiculous so take your chances with another brand.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed!
Reviews.Author: Alli Tignor
Reviews.Content: I was so excited to get this camera as a wedding gift and take it on our cruise.  However, on the first night of our honeymoon we realized how terrible the quality of the indoor pictures were.  We spent a couple of hours trying every setting and nothing worked to make them better.  We actually had to buy another camera on the cruise to get decent indoor pictures.  I will say that the outdoor pictures turned out well, as did the ones that we took in the water.  It is definitely waterproof.  The one difficulty was that it was virtually impossible to see what you were hoping to shoot when underwater.  I would definitely recommend selecting something else.

Reviews.Title: Waterproof my A**
Reviews.Author: Alix.G
Reviews.Content: Took this camera on vacation to Key West... the first night we were there I took two or three photos about a foot underwater because the box clearly says waterproof up to 16 feet!  This camera is NOT waterproof at all.  The screen instantly went black and when I opened the battery a ton of water poured out.  I had no camera for the rest of my vacation.  SO MAD.  Do not take this camera underwater!!

Reviews.Title: Not Waterproof
Reviews.Author: Sandra J. Walimaa
Reviews.Content: Do not purchase this camera especially if you have any thoughts of it getting even a little bit wet.  Within seconds of going into Hanuama Bay in Honolulu the camera no longer worked.  It was in about 1 foot of water so well within the 16 feet that the camera supposedly works.  Fuji was not helpful when I called the issue in.  I bought the camera at Costco more than 90 days ago, but had never tried it in water until now.  Costco connected me with Fuji who said I could pay to have the camera repaired even though it is clearly a defect in their product.  I threw the camera away and will never buy another Fuji product.  I will also tell everyone I know never to buy a Fuji product.  The quality of the photos outside of water was also very poor for the cost of the camera and it is supposed to be 14 mp.  Do not buy this camera.

Reviews.Title: better off getter form best buy
Reviews.Author: David R
Reviews.Content: Camera leaked after 2 time in pool.  Went and bought a new one from Best buy- better design. this camera is not water tight.

Reviews.Title: Went TOO Deep and Hard!
Reviews.Author: Edith Bunker
Reviews.Content: // To view this video download Flash Player (version 9.0.115 or higher)'); } } catch(err) { fp_resizePlayerSpace('cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02A', 0, 0); } return false; } function _cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02AloadSwf(movieID, playerVersion) { var swfLocation = "http://g-ecx.images-amazon.com/images/G/01/am3/20120510035744301/AMPlayer._V148501545_.swf"; } cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02AloadSwf_Core(swfLocation, swfWidth, swfHeight, flashVersion, bgColor, swfParams, flashParams, embedAttributes); return false; } function cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02AloadSwf(movieID, playerVersion) { return _cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02AloadSwf(movieID, playerVersion); } // ]]> var cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02ARollOverImg = new Image(); cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02ARollOverImg.src = "http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/91Iao3CKLFS._SX320_PHcustomer-video-vignette_PIvideo-reviews-bottom,BottomLeft,0,43_OU01_PIcustomer-video-play-active,BottomLeft,130,-12_CR0,0,0,0_.png"; var cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02Apreplay = document.getElementById('cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02ApreplayImageId'); if (cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02Apreplay) { cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02Apreplay.onmouseover = function() { cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02Apreplay.src = "http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/91Iao3CKLFS._SX320_PHcustomer-video-vignette_PIvideo-reviews-bottom,BottomLeft,0,43_OU01_PIcustomer-video-play-active,BottomLeft,130,-12_CR0,0,0,0_.png"; } cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02Apreplay.onmouseout = function() { cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02Apreplay.src = "http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/91Iao3CKLFS._SX320_PHcustomer-video-vignette_PIvideo-reviews-bottom,BottomLeft,0,43_OU01_PIcustomer-video-play,BottomLeft,130,-12_CR0,0,0,0_.png"; } var node = cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02Apreplay.parentNode; var cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02AcurrentClick = node.onclick; node.onclick = function () { var head = document.getElementsByTagName("head"); if (head[0]) { var logTag = document.createElement('script'); logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02AcurrentClick) { return cv_mo16MB1G6KNZ02AcurrentClick(); } } } Length:: 0:37 MinsBefore you get the wrong idea, read the rightfully best-rated review by R. Zamudio, "Good adventure cam, especially for the price. August 14, 2011."This is actually my second XP20. I lost the first one in a wave while filming first-person videos of bodyboarding at Venice Beach. Definitely, an investment in a brightly colored flotation device or a more secure strap would be a wise choice if you're planning to take the camera into less than crystal clear waters. And as you can see, I liked the XP20 so much and had such great results with it in pools and surf (and on dry land) that I purchased my second one.After two years of trustworthy perfomance, the second XP20 ended up waterlogged with water visibly sloshing around in the display screen and fogging up the lens--when I opened the battery hatch, a stream of water poured out. The camera is now sitting with both hatches (the battery and USB) open in the hopes that it will be salvageable, but with a dried up residue on the inner side of the lens, it's not looking very good. The SD card is also drying out and I'm hoping to be able to access the last photos/videos taken. The battery looks fine (hopefully the newer Fujifilm XPs are using the same battery... the more extreme XP200 makes me drool).This review was actually going to be a 3-star or less review, but then I remembered that I had been diving down to depths that were possibly below 16 feet and the R. Zamudio review explained the other extreme conditions that I ignorantly inflicted upon the camera."I also realize how important the seals are on an underwater camera, so I regularly clean the seals at the battery compartment and apply a bit of chap stick with my pinky to keep a good pliable seal." --R. ZamudioIn the two years I have had the camera, I never cleaned/lubricated the seals. They were starting to look kinda dry, and I would occasionally see very light moisture around the inside of the hatches of the battery-USB compartments, but it never affected the XP20's performance, so I continued using it as usual."This means that if the camera is exposed to a force of water greater than 7 PSI, chances are the seals will be overwhelmed and fail. This can happen while trying to take this camera surfing and having a wave crash on top of you. This can happen if you were to drop it off of a fairly high bridge into water. It can happen if it is in your pocket when you are in water and your movements are trapping and forcing water against the camera. It can happen if you are going down a fast slide at a waterpark with the camera and hit the splashdown pool with speed." -- R. ZamudioAaahhh! The brain light finally switched on... these are exactly the conditions I have been using to abuse my poor XP 20. Flipping off diving boards with it, bodysurfing/bodyboarding, and the action that finally killed my XP20, jumping off a 16 foot cliff into a pool of more or less the same depth of flowing waterfall run-off. I jumped multiple times with the camera in my hands and/or pocket. By the time I realized something was wrong, water was sloshing around the display and the lens was fogged up.The XP20 survived everything else up to this point. Because of reviews I had read 2 years ago (before R. Zamudio's), I was always careful to check the seals and make sure the hatch buttons were always clicked tightly upwards. I only worried about exceeding the depth rating and was completely ignorant of water impact pressures.Would I purchase the XP20 again? Sure, if it was the only model available, but after seeing the 49.2' rated XP200 (placing a mug under my lips to capture the drool), I'm definitely thinking about forking over bigger bucks for the upgrade (if only it had an impact/extreme sports rating...).Negatives of the XP20:Though I love (loved) my XP20, when compared with other digital cameras I own/have owned, it did have a bit of a Neanderthal feel to it. Primitive, but in a nice retro way. For example, the zoom was quite noisy and it was quite a finicky camera--I don't know if my technique was poor, but it often took a few shots to get an unblurry photo, though at other times it would perform brilliantly. I can't complain about the quality of the undewater shots/videos, they always amazed me with their beauty and the wonderful sounds recorded as the camera went below the surface in video mode.Overall though, I feel my investment in 2 XP20s was worth it, though it would have been nice to still have my functioning second XP20, if I had read R. Zamudio's review...I would recommend that you purchase the higher model XP200 if you're planning to abuse the camera like me. I did experience very light leakage that didn't compromise the camera when jumping off of normal backyard swimming pool diving boards and when taking it on bodyboarding rides in light surf, but I may just have been lucky up until now.

Reviews.Title: Easy to use
Reviews.Author: David A. Davidson
Reviews.Content: This camera is great for anyone who enjoys water sports. Fishing year round is what I do and I can rely on this camera for great pictures in any weather conditions.

Reviews.Title: Great rugged camera
Reviews.Author: Ben Berauer
Reviews.Content: This camera is rugged.  My only two minor criticisms are that the battery/SD card compartment door is both difficult to lock, and seems a bit flimsy, and the camera power button can be activated by accident if you have it in a soft case and it bumps something.But it is a very nice waterproof, dustproof, shockproof little camera at a very good price, making it a good value.Shipping and overall handling by the provider is very good.

Reviews.Title: Not waterproof. Camera dies
Reviews.Author: g2
Reviews.Content: This camera is not waterproof. I took it in the swimming pool and the camera failed. The battery door opens and the camera dies. Also had issue with some of the control buttons. I don't recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Okay underwater camera
Reviews.Author: brooklyn2012
Reviews.Content: We bought Fujifilm Finepix XP20 about 6 months ago for our trip to Hawaii.We chose XP20 because it was on the cheaper side of underwater digital cameras.Here's few fine points you should be aware of:1) Underwater Shooting- XP20 takes best pictures when underwater compared to its outdoor, indoor, and nighttime pictures.- Make use the USB and battery doors are completely closed and clicked into place before going underwater- Waterproof function is hit or miss. Our first XP20 died after its second day underwater (immediately returned to store for full refund). Our second XP20 worked well underwater. So far no water leaks. For added reassurance, I added layer of petroleum jelly/Vaseline to all sides of USB/battery doors. It worked well and I don't have to worry about camera malfunction in the water.- It is hard to see what you taking pictures of underwater on the LCD screen due to glare. We just point and shoot in the direction of interest. I was only able to see the LCD screen underwater on cloudy days.- Picture is definitely better than those underwater one-time-use point-and-shoot disposable cameras2) Other picture modes when compared to other 14MP digital cameras- Poor picture quality indoors (flash is not that bright)- Sub par picture quality when outdoors- It is not a good all purpose digital camera3) LCD screen- Clear display of pictures- Camera computer is very slow compared to other digital cameras- Review of pictures tend to load much slower4) Camera lens- Camera lens is located on the corner- Easy to get smudge due to location- Make sure camera lens is clean or else picture will have smudge/cloudy haze

Reviews.Title: Good Backup
Reviews.Author: Kurt Thomas "Adventurous type"
Reviews.Content: I got this as an upgrade from the Z33 WP, which I had purchased for one snorkel excursion off the SE Florida coast, where it got me a decent shot of a large, but unusually friendly barracuda. Naturally I was excited to find an improvement to that model's basic offerings. I have enjoyed the small increase in zoom and the deeper depth-capability. I also used it to introduce my 7 year-old nephew to photography, who proved it to be quite kid-proof. Picture quality in broad daylight has been acceptable. Face recognition and scene recognition software is quite good. Macro-shots of insects and flowers during hikes have been surprisingly good. The only faults I have found with this model are a battery door that takes a little muscle to shut properly and lousy indoor/low light capabilities. Indoor shots with the flash, if you're not within 5 feet-forget it. Indoor shots actually come out better if you can stabilize the camera and take the shot in Natural Picture mode, without flash. Also, battery life is just okay.

Reviews.Title: Great photos only if there is enough light
Reviews.Author: Myles A. Voigt
Reviews.Content: IF you plan on taking photos in dark areas (including in your house during the day) do not buy this piece of crap. This is the worst camera I have ever seen/owned for dark photos. I took a bunch of photos using different settings and none of them look good. They are blurry (while on a table no less), the color sucks, and get this, the night settings were the worst ones! However, if you are in pretty good lighting (outside in the sun) or using the flash (which sometimes isn't appropriate) this camera takes excellent photos. I have not used it under water or dropped it yet, so I can't say how well it works in that respect. If you want a versatile camera look elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: Battery cover.
Reviews.Author: Patty
Reviews.Content: I bought this as a Christmas gift for my daughter.  It is disappointing when a gift does not work.  She didn't get a chance to try the camera out.  She couldn't get the battery cover to stay closed.  She opened it to put the battery in & that is as far as she got.  Amazon is exchanging it for me, which I appreciate.  I hope she doesn't have the same problem with the new one.

Reviews.Title: NOT AN UNDERWATER CAMERA!!!!
Reviews.Author: Katrina
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera specifically to take with me on a cruise. I read over all the reviews here and figured that I could some how figure it out and not have any problems. WRONG. The first time I take it underwater it drowns itself. And YES I made sure the latch was closed and made a soft click noise. I also made sure that both of the little botton were to the same side with no yellow showing. AND STILLED LEAKED.The pictures before hand were nice and I enjoyed its size but IT DOESN'T LAST UNDER WATER. Just buy it for above land shots. Take it underwater at your own risk.

Reviews.Title: Don't buy it.
Reviews.Author: Suzanna walters "meow"
Reviews.Content: We purchased this camera for a stay at Great Wolf lodge. The first day, we were really impressed with it!  We took AMAZING water video and pictures and couldn't wait to download and see everything on the computer screen. Because we took so many videos, the battery wore down, and that evening, long after we were dressed and dry, we took the battery out and placed it in the charger. The next morning, we popped the battery back in but my husband noticed there was a slight film growing on the viewing screen.  Not ten minutes later, the camera wouldn't turn on at all and now, eight hours later, it's obvious the thing's completely waterlogged. The screen is ringed with moisture and now we don't know if we can even access our movies because we didn't set it up prior to going to the lodge. We never opened the thing anywhere near the waterpark, so I know that's not the culprit. I'd save your receipt if you want to take the gamble and put it in a safe place, preparing for the possibility for returning it.

Reviews.Title: Bad camera
Reviews.Author: Martin Cooper
Reviews.Content: As the previous reviewer said, a bad camera. Poor pictures inside are dark. Unfocused, blurry pictures. Poor colours. Awkward to use and hold. Fingers get in front of the lens.My 3 year old Canon P&S; takes better pictures.

Reviews.Title: Poor design for Water resistivity
Reviews.Author: ED F "ShutterBug"
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Fuji XP 20 camera prior to a cruise with my 8 year old daughter with the expectation of capturing some of the shore excursions that we had booked. These included snorkeling and hand feeding stingrays. On the first use, in less than 2 feet of water, the battery compartment seal leaked and the camera was useless from that point on. And yes I did read all the directions, ensured that the latch was fully locked. I rated this item a 1 star because a negative number was not available. I did return the camera and received a full refund... The moments I expected to capture are gone forever, except for or memories. The only reason for this review is to prevent this from happening to someone else.

Reviews.Title: Do not buy this camera if you want to take it in the water!!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I would give this camera no stars if I could since I got it specifically to use in and on the water.  It takes great pictures out of the water and has lots of great settings, but when I took it in the water, it quit working within 5 minutes and now refuses to come back on.  Before I went in, I checked to make sure the battery compartment was completely closed, but water still got in somehow.  Now I have a camera that is less than a year old that won't work and probably is going to cost more than I paid for it to have it repaired.  If you're looking for a waterproof camera spend your money elsewhere!!! This is a bad investment.

Reviews.Title: awful little camera
Reviews.Author: jonathan
Reviews.Content: I had this camera for 2 days and returned it.  I immediately hated it.  It was difficult to use and took terrible pictures on every setting.  About half the times I tried to take a picture it was freeze up trying to focus and I would miss my shot.  I never tried it under water but it feels cheap and bulky.  I doubt it would take good pictures under water if it can't take them any where else.  My 7 year old sony cybershot takes WAY better pictures, as does my olympus waterproof that got dropped one too many times to still be waterproof - got water logged and dried out.  I'm going to get another olympus waterproof (and not treat it like it's bulletproof).

Reviews.Title: The Fujifilm XP20 Quick Review
Reviews.Author: Ronald Jones "silent knight"
Reviews.Content: I recently purchased this camera for use on the beach (not underwater). This is the cheapest of the "tough" cameras on the market. Outside pictures were very good. Inside with a flash left a lot to be desired, but this is an outside camera, not an all purpose. The LCD is clear, the menu is easy to navigate. It is a very easy to use camera. It is small and thin and quite attractive. The only real weak spot is the battery compartment door cover. It is very flimsy and can be problematic to get it to close and latch properly. To me this is very worrisome because sooner or later it is going to get wet either by inadvertently dunking it in the ocean or by being rinsed to get sand off of it. So, if you can live with the weak battery door cover this is a good outside camera.

Reviews.Title: NOT WATERPROOF!!!
Reviews.Author: boostedK20
Reviews.Content: For the guy who took it diving and it still works: Glad it worked for you. I bought it for a trip to Hawaii with my kids and took it snorkeling on the last day we were there. Within 5 minutes the screen stopped working, an hour later it was completely dead. Somehow water got in it. Like everyone else, I read the instructions, all the latches were properly closed, that wasn't even the compartment that got wet! The other side of the camera is where the water seeped in. I checked the battery and memory card were completely dry, THANK GOSH! So I didn't loose all my pics. Luckily enough the captain felt bad and gave us a free cheapy underwater camera for the rest of the trip. I was so unhappy, it was such a disappointment!

Reviews.Title: Fuji, please make a camera better than the one you made 5 years ago.
Reviews.Author: Blade "Blade"
Reviews.Content: Extremely let down by this camera.  I have its much older cousin, the Olympus 850.  The IQ from the Oly is so much better.  When my iphone pictures look clearer and sharper, there is something very wrong.  The pictures from this thing look like pastel drawing.I really wanted to like this camera, on paper its great, in real life, a let down.  Please end the megapixel wars, I want clean pictures, not 14 megs of noise.

Reviews.Title: Looks cool... that's about it.
Reviews.Author: Robert L Medlin
Reviews.Content: After taking a couple of "test" photos upon opening the box up, I thought I had a winner.  However, upon taking it out into the surf for its intended use, I was VERY disappointed.  While I had no issues with water getting in, the picture quality was horrific.  Most pictures were out of focus and I'm wondering if drops on the lense (which how can you help that when the camera is in the water - where its designed to be), are the root cause.  Perhaps it can't adequately focus under these conditions.  Anyway, the color was also reason for concern under the "auto" setting.  However, I have an SLR and another point and shoot if high quality pics are the priority, it was the video aspect of this camera that excited me - two cameras in one that could brave the waves with me.  I was mistaken.  The video quality was indescribably poor... washed out with little color and again, the camera was consistently out of focus.  I'm taking it back.  This camera simply doesn't perform well IN the water.

ProductInfo.Features:
14 million effective pixels; 1/2.3 inch CCD with primary color filter; 5x optical zoom lens plus approx 6.8x digital zoom
2.7 inch TFT color LCD monitor; HD movie 720p with sound; One touch underwater movie recording
Waterproof, dustproof, shockproof and freeze proof
Dual image stabilization; Face Detection; Auto red-eye removal; Tracking auto focus; 6 scene SR AUTO; Motion Panorama mode with auto stitch
USB 2.0 High-speed; Video output NTSC / PAL selectable; SD/SDHC memory card slot (card NOT included)
ProductInfo.Name: Fujifilm FinePix XP20 Blue 14 MP Digital Camera with 5x Optical Zoom and 2.7-Inch LCD
